section-block.rac_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Poor Eddie lost his teddy in the dark woods. Join Eddie as he searches for his teddy and has some unexpected encounters.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Oo and Pp Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: O is for octopus. I spy an octopus. Who can show me what I spy? Use both sides of the cards.
Invite children to join in as you sing “The Alphabet Song.” Sing slowly and have children stand when they hear the letter that begins their names.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Where’s My Teddy? by Jez Alborough.
Pablo loves this make-believe narrative about a boy, a bear, and their teddies.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why does Eddie go into the woods?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Listen as I read aloud these pages. What’s the name of Eddie’s teddy? Do you notice anything about the names Eddie and Freddie? They rhyme! Words rhyme if they have the same ending sounds.
Eddie lost his teddy bear. He imagines that he goes off into the woods to find it.
How does Eddie feel as he searches the woods? What sounds do you think Eddie hears in the woods?
What surprises Eddie now? What does Eddie think about the giant teddy? What are some clues in the picture that tell you how Eddie feels? (MB)
What do you see in the picture? Do you think Eddie sees Freddie?
Who do you think is more frightened—the bear or Eddie? Why? (MB)
The bear and Eddie both went to bed with their own teddy bears. Do you ever snuggle in bed with a teddy bear?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why does Eddie go into the woods?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He goes into the woods to look for his bear.
He can’t find his teddy bear.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about the different-sized bears in the story, as children listen. Have children draw pictures for one of the sentences you write.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Eddie go into the woods to find his bear?
Eddie goes into the woods to find his b______ (bear).
Eddie goes into the woods to find his bear.
What did Eddie and the bear both do with their own bears?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Teaching children letter names is great, but teaching the sounds that letters represent is the first step in growing children’s pre-reading skills. During Circle Time activities, the teacher provides a word orally. This directs the child’s attention to the sound first. Only after the sound is identified is the connection to the letter made.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Understand Feelings and Actions
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion by saying: There are hard days when I feel grumpy. Is it okay to feel grumpy? Yes, it is! Is it okay to yell at my friends because I’m grumpy? No! If I’m grumpy, I can let my friends know with my words that I don’t feel like playing. Maybe I want to be by myself for awhile. Who can tell about a time they felt that way? What did you do?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about the Mind Builder. We will try to understand the feelings and actions of the boy and the bear as we revisit Where’s My Teddy? by Jez Alborough.
Clifford loves this book because he once lost his bear and understands how Eddie feels.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind BuilderUse Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Eddie feel about being in the woods? What is he missing?
Something made Eddie stop. What scares Eddie? Show me how Eddie looked when he was scared. What do you do when you are scared? (MB)
Eddie thinks his tiny teddy bear has changed into a giant teddy bear. How does Eddie feel about this change? (MB)
Look at how the gigantic bear is holding the tiny teddy. How does the gigantic bear feel about having a tiny teddy? (MB)
Imagine you are Eddie and you see a giant bear walking toward you. How would you feel? What would you do? (MB)
Where are both Eddie and the bear going?

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to stand in a circle and act out the story as you give the following prompts: Pretend you’re Eddie. You’re sad because you can’t find your bear. You walk, walk, walk into the woods. Now you look, look, look, for the bear. You see a gigantic teddy bear and you’re so surprised that you jump! Then you look way, way, way up at the teddy. Soon, you see a real gigantic bear with a tiny teddy. You take your tiny bear and run, run, run home. And you snuggle in your bed with Freddie. Now show me how you can go and be ready for our writing activity. (MB)

Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about things in the room that are big and small. For example, they might say we have a big car and a small car in the block corner. When children name objects, encourage them to write the letter for the sound they hear at the beginning of the words.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Before children have the vocabulary to express their feelings, they do so through facial expressions, body language, and behaviors. Children need to be taught to put names to feelings before they can learn to self-regulate their reactions. Acknowledge the feelings first, and then model appropriate responses to them as opportunities arise. (Martinelli, n.d.)

section-block.rac_body-text: Present children with two different toy teddy bears or other stuffed animals. Invite children to compare them and tell how they are alike and how they are different.

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Freddie and Eddie have names that rhyme. Let’s listen. Clap if you hear two words that rhyme: bear/chair; bed/Ted; little/big; woods/trees; dark/park; huddle/cuddle; boy/toy.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Where’s My Teddy? by Jez Alborough.
Pablo likes narratives because they tell stories that are fun to listen to and read.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
How are Eddie and the gigantic bear alike?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Eddie find? Was the giant teddy bear bigger or smaller than Eddie?
Look at the pictures. How does Eddie know the giant teddy bear won’t fit in his bed?
How do you think it would sound if a gigantic bear was stomping through the woods? Show me what stomping looks like. How does it sound?
I see the letter p in the word stomping. Can you point to it? What sound does the letter p make?
What do you notice about the size of the teddy bear in the gigantic bear’s arms?
Look at Ted in the bear’s bed. Does it still look big, small, or just the right size? Look at Freddie in Eddie’s bed. How do you know it’s just the right size for Eddie?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How are Eddie and the gigantic bear alike?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They are afraid of each other.
They both found teddy bears of the wrong size.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to talk and write about comparing how Eddie and the bear are alike.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did Eddie and the giant bear find teddy bears of the wrong size?
Eddie and the giant bear found teddy bears of the wrong s____ (size).
Eddie and the giant bear found teddy bears of the wrong size.
In what ways are Eddie and the bear different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children are engaged in measurement activities without even realizing it. “Fairness” is very important to preschoolers, so they’re acutely aware if someone else “got more” or “has a bigger piece.” When you overhear such conversations, build upon children’s understanding by asking, How do you know? How can we measure that?

section-block.rac_body-text: Place items of two different sizes where children can see but not feel them. Have children determine which one is heavy and which one is light. Repeat.
Share the chant: Measure your hand, then measure your nose; Measure your feet and measure your toes; You’re smiling, you’re happy. Let’s measure your grin!
Introduce new words that will be helpful when talking about measurement.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read the poster I Can Measure. We’ll look at the words and pictures to find ways to measure things.
Pablo loves to read informational texts about measuring and look at all of the tools.
In Where’s My Teddy? we saw bears of different sizes. On the I Can Measure poster, we see ways to measure length, weight, amount, and temperature.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it helps us answer the concept question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many

section.rac_body-text: Share the poster with children. Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Use these prompts to read and discuss the poster.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Each picture is labeled with the name of a measuring tool. Point to the word ruler. What does the ruler show us about the crayon and the pencil?
What is the boy weighing on the scale? Which is light? Which is heavy? How can you tell?

Point to the label for the cup. What sound do you hear at the end of cup? What letter stands for the /p/ sound? What is the girl using these cups to measure? Now, point to the cup that is full. Point to the cup that is empty,
Look at the thermometer. Which picture shows something cold? Which one shows something hot?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to go on a hunt. Assign children partners. Ask pairs to search the room to find two things that are exactly the same size. Then have them find two things that are alike but have different sizes. When children have finished, have them join a circle to share what they found. Then have children practice their transition to their writing activity. (MB)
Provide a writing prompt about using one measuring tool. Help children write the letter for the sound they hear at the beginning of words. Give support as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research suggests that reading stories in one language at a time is the best approach in a multilingual classroom, even if two languages appear on a page. However, research has also shown that explaining what a story will be about, in both languages (if possible), prior to reading is a beneficial practice for all children as well.

section-block.rac_body-text: We’ve been reading Where’s My Teddy? Let’s pretend to be Eddie when he sees the giant teddy. Model looking up high at the gigantic bear and trying to wrap your arms around it for a cuddle. Have children act out being the bear and holding the tiny teddy.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Where’s My Teddy? by Jez Alborough.
This narrative is fiction. That means it is a make-believe story. Pablo loves to read stories about teddy bears.
This week, we read about different ways to measure. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why wouldn’t you take the giant teddy home?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can pretend they’re searching for a lost toy? Invite a child to act the part. Then invite everyone to join in the search.
It says Eddie tiptoed. Who can show me what it means to tiptoe? When would you tiptoe?
Pretend you are Eddie sitting on the giant teddy. Your hands are under your chin. What are you thinking about?
Now let’s pretend we see a giant bear. This time it’s the real bear, not a stuffed bear! Show me how your face might look. Tell me what you might want to do. (MB)
Now it’s time to snuggle in bed. Pretend you are Eddie and huddle and cuddle with Freddie.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why wouldn’t you take the giant teddy home?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use the Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: It’s too big to carry home.
It’s too big to snuggle and fit in my bed.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write. Note when children are moving from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondences for beginning and end sounds.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the giant teddy too big for Eddie?
The giant teddy is too b____ (big) for Eddie.
The giant teddy is too big for Eddie.
What size bear would be the right size for you?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: At this age, children are moving from scribbles to marks that stand for something specific. When asked, children will explain that they’ve written a grocery list, a to-do list, or some other specific type of writing. Provide daily writing opportunities, such as setting up a sign-in and sign-out routine where children practice writing their names.
